Award.AwardTitle: Expanding Career and Educational Learning in Information Technology (EXCEL-IT)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Students with an interest in science, technology, engineering, and math careers find transitions from high school to community college to four year degree programs to be particularly challenging. Early college and dual-credit programs in high school can support students in successfully transitioning to college-level work. The Expanding Career and Educational Learning in Information Technology (EXCEL-IT) project will prepare for college-level work over 900 high school students in a diverse and economically-challenged area of Washington State. The project will involve dual-enrollment IT courses taught in high schools by trained, certified, and well-supported instructors using a hybrid online/classroom structure. Students will be able to earn both high school and college credit, as well as take free certification exams for industry-recognized credentials. This project will contribute to the development of a 2+2+2 STEM degree pathway, with support from the Washington State Board for Community and Technical Colleges. The goal of the project is to directly address the growing shortage of qualified IT professionals and generate useful data and practices for high schools and colleges to recruit and prepare a larger and more diverse body of students for IT careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Expanding Career and Educational Learning in Information Technology (EXCEL-IT) sought to diversify the technology talent pipeline by establishing a concurrent enrollment partnership ecosystem and infrastructure to provide underrepresented, underserved, and place-bound students access to access college-level courses and entry-level certification and career opportunities in information technology, while allowing students continued access to support systems and services already in place at students’ high schools. The project served students in highly diverse and economically challenged community in Washington State.

EXCEL-IT served as a platform to establish and deliver concurrent enrollment partnership courses: college courses in information technology offered at local high schools, taught by certified high school faculty. Five high school teachers received professional development and were certified to teach concurrent enrollment partnership courses and the computer infrastructure was established to allow high school students to remotely access the same computing facilities that are made available to college students in information technology courses. EXCEL-IT helped to establish a precedent on how concurrent enrollment courses can be offered in career and technical education, based on evidence and best practices, which was previously was not available in the project’s service area. 

EXCEL-IT established a similar partnership with the Muckleshoot Tribal College, opening up a new pathway for tribal college students to access information technology courses being taught on-location at the tribal college. Two instructors were recruited, trained, and certified to offer concurrent enrollment courses in information technology and participated in professional development and mentorship activities with EXCEL-IT senior project personnel and tribal college administrators. An initial cohort of 26 tribal college students have enrolled in information technology courses in the partnership program. It is anticipated that students in the initial cohort at the Muckleshoot Tribe will earn their associate degree (conferred by Green River College) in Spring 2020 and will be eligible to continue into an applied baccalaureate degree program that is designed to enable students to access a broader range of entry-level careers in information technology.


Last Modified: 11/16/2019
Modified by: Kendrick Hang
